display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 738px; height: 1px; padding-top: 460px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
This is an example of a false trade-off, where the extreme viewpoints seem mutually exclusive, like you can only choose one, but in reality, there are many options in between, which can be found with reality-covering variables, to find integration structures where both viewpoints can get what they want, as often these extremes have similarities such as similar errors, as they're both usually false structures in some way.
For example, one extreme might be to 'get rid of inconvenient people with problems' and another extreme might be to 'pretend everything is fine and everyone has the same resources'. Both of these structures create the same error which is to 'avoid solving problems (one by explicit intent and one by pretending all problems are solvable by all people)'.
In reality, 'improving intelligence of all agents' is a useful integration structure that avoids this trade-off, as it distributes the primary inequality/difference creating the problem (inequal intelligence/ability), and avoids both pretending all resources possessed by agents are equal and avoids killing unnecessarily and creates more problem-solvers.

switch.text: This is an example of a false trade-off, where the extreme viewpoints seem mutually exclusive, like you can only choose one...

div.div: Rather than the below false trade-off structure, where one extreme is required to be selected.

div.div: An integrated solution finding the common structure of both extreme viewpoints (one indicating that 'problem-solving is too difficult' and the other indicating that 'everyone can solve all the same problems the same optimal ways', both involving 'problem-solving complexity'), at which point, its possible to apply differences (independent/orthogonal vectors, such as decreasing problem-solving complexity, by increasing problem-solving ability/distribution and increasing problem-solvers.

switch.text: An integrated solution finding the common structure of both extreme viewpoints...

div.div: Vector toward decreasing problem-solving complexity (an orthogonal variable added to solve the problem and resolve the false trade-off).
